Consider a complex function defined as \\( z(t) = e^{iAt}x \\), where \\( A \\) is a constant matrix and \\( x \\) is a constant vector in complex space. This function is used to transform an initial vector in a complex vector space. We investigate the influence of applying an additional transformation \\( g(z) = e^{Dt}z \\) at a time t, where \\( D \\) is also a constant matrix.

If \\( z(t) \\) operates on a vector \\( x \\) at t = 0 and progresses naturally under the transformation \\( z(t) = e^{iAt}x \\) without further modifications, will the vector at t = T be the same as if \\( x \\) had just evolved to t = T under \\( z(t) = e^{iAt}x \\)?
Explanation: In this scenario, since the transformation \\( e^{iAt} \\) is applied from the beginning and continuously influences the vector \\( x \\) in a predefined manner, the state at any time t = T will simply be a result of this uninterrupted transformation, resulting in \\( z(T) = e^{iAT}x \\).
